data.text: Portable Water Filtration System on Bicycle Tours
Do you take any type of portable water filtration system on tour, and if so what do you use and why?
Sawyer. It's bombproof and cheap. Keep them at home and in all earthquake kits. Back flushes and does more water than you could ever drink.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: the bags that come with the the filter ,suck. I've had many fail
data.author: Edward Gregory

data.text: No. Longest I‚Äôve ever gone between water sources was 100 miles and the two bottles I had lasted me. Backpacking I have a Katadyn BeFree.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: another vote for Katadyn BeFree. Works great
data.author: Lauri Paulsen

data.text: Sawyer squeeze, because it's small and simple
data.author: Gert Pellin

data.text: A steri pen or a sawyer mini. I use them because they are small and more than adequate for occasional use
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: Filtration is always a bit tricky. One might filter out bugs, not virus. And good luck with pesticides, heavy metals etc. An underestimated solution: uv light. Kill ‚Äúeverything that has a dna‚Äù. Cooking as well, but takes longer. Something I like: a connection that can be attached to ‚Äúany‚Äù tap so the larger bottles can be filled. ü§ì
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: Depends on the needs of the tour. I use my Sweetwater Guardian when needed, but usually it is not needed.
data.author: William Griggs

data.text: Yes, i use a Be Free collapsible bottle, and have used it often both cycling and hiking. I only stay away from stagnant water...
data.author: Paolo Marchiori

data.text:
https://iconlifesaver.com/products/bottles/ - the bottle is reliable but bulky. The liberty is great! Small, lightweight, can mount in Nalgene bottles, uses hose to reach water, simple pumping mechanism. Works great. Downside: may not freeze! Otherwise it's gone.
Water Purifier Bottles - Travel, Backpacking, Hiking, Outdoor - LifeSaver
iconlifesaver.com
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: I carry the Sawyer Squeeze. It‚Äôs small and works well.
data.author: Paul Lieberman

data.text:
We have a sawyer mini excellent bit of kit https://velotouring.fun/review-sawyer-mini-water-filter
Review Sawyer Mini Water Filter
velotouring.fun
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text: , that bag works OK but I wore one out. I recommend the filter and that bag with a 2L Platypus bag for more storage and asa backup. Carry iodone tabs for an extra piece of mind for the nastier water and I think you're good for most places except for chemical considerations, which is a whole different level of filtration.
data.author: Boxcar Willie

data.text: ...also carry two Sawyer filters so you have a backup in case one gets too clogged.
data.author: Boxcar Willie

data.text: Platypus meta. It fits in a water bottle cage. It holds 750ml so doubles as water storage.
data.author: Jason Roussel

data.text: Katadyn My Bottle and chlorine mix bottles Pristine
data.author: Marc Pilon

data.text: Sawyer Mini, all the way
data.author: Josh Dunn

data.text: Generic life straw filter. Fits on mini pump mount on downtube. $12-15(USD). Threaded to fit coke bottle.
data.author: Rob  Marines

data.text: I carry a life straw as backup. The weight is insignificant. I have not yet needed to use it.
data.author: Thomas Wilson

data.text: Sawyer Mini has excellent filtration, and is one of the lighter and more compact items available. That being said, if my water sources aren‚Äôt intersecting agricultural of human activity I don‚Äôt bother bringing it. I‚Äôve had hundreds of gallons of back country and lake water and never had an issue just using good judgement.
data.author: Kevin Medick

data.text: yet, knock on wood. One case of Giardia will change your mind.

data.text: - need our water filter?
data.author: Susan Kopczynski Jostrom

data.text: Chlorine drops. Quick, easy, kills virii, doesn't freeze, doesn't taste like iodine, eats up less'n two oz and 0.1 liter space.
data.author: John Almond

data.text: Platypus gravityworks. Filters directly into my bladders without needing to remove them from packs, while I chill or sleep or whatever.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: I have one. It‚Äôs some box store brand, I grabbed it as an afterthought and it is buried in my bags because I won‚Äôt need it until I can find wild water. The few times I‚Äôve seen wild water was after I filled up already
data.author: Nesta Skychild

data.text: Aquamira drops, or katydyn befree. A strong "no thanks" to the sawyer mini. Terrible fill bag, terrible flow rate.
data.author: Leif Warner

data.text: A few micropour doses. Light and easy to store :)
data.author: Justus Baer

data.text: I carry one in Alaska here
data.author: Seth Landon

data.text: Katadyn gravity filters are the best. I'll never go back to the pump. Scoop the water and have as much as you need at your camp site.
data.author: RG Pilt

data.text: Steripen UV. Small, quick, safe and not liable to undetectable freeze/thaw damage like the micro-filter types.
data.author: Steve Holland

data.text: Thanks for all the great info‚Ä¶.gives me a lot to review
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: Remember that particle size is as the cube of diameter. A 0.2 micron particle has eight times the volume of a 0.1 micron particle.
data.author: Jack Kessler

data.text:
Don't get anything but the Platypus Gravity Feed PLEASE!!! Weightless, effective, simple and does 4 litres at a time. https://www.platy.com/ca/filtration/gravityworks-water-filter-system-6.0l4.0l/gravityworks.html

data.text: Be free
data.author: Patricia Roth

data.text: when I used to do remote touring if it was in an area that probably required me getting water from unknown sources I used the Sawyer squeeze system. If it's a remote possibility I carried purification tablets. I preferred Portable Aqua.
data.author: David Rubin
